description: Through reading texts of Plato (Socrates), Aristotle, Augustine and Aquinas, the student encounters a range of political ideas deeply challenging to--and possibly corrosive of--today's dominant democratic liberalism. Can classical and medieval thinking offer insight into modern impasses in political morality? Is such ancient thinking plausible, useful, or dangerous?
name: ANCIENT POLITICAL THOUGH

values.comments: Virtually all the student reviews complained that Professor Shiffman was very quiet, difficult to hear throughout his lectures. However, it appears that he improved on that progressively during the semester. Organization was not one of the professor’s strong points. Students loved many of the readings, but said that the book was rather expensive considering how many pages the professor actually assigned. Some students loved the material, saying “this was the type of class I came to college for” and that it “taught me a lot not only in terms of academics but also in terms of life in general.”
